title: Here are five ways Theresa May can make immigration work for post-Brexit Britain
text:
23 February 2017 • 10:43am A rethink of immigration is needed if post-Brexit Britain is to succeed 
T he public voted to leave the European Union and so “take back control” on many issues, not least immigration. While pledging to reducing net migration to the tens of thousands, the latest figures remain at all-time highs and more now than at any time under New Labour. Latest figures showing a fall to 273,000 is still more than two and a half times the government’s target since 2010 – and the drop is fuelled by more non-EU citizens who are unaffected by Brexit leaving and taking their skills elsewhere. 
There are five things that Theresa May can do to create a much better immigration plan for post-Brexit Britain: 
First, May should focus more on reducing impact than numbers. Public concerns about net migration centre on real or perceived pressures on school places, finding employment, getting on the housing ladder and NHS waiting times.
